lines.text:
[finds Marlene in the trunk of the car]
Get out of there! It's against the law to ride in the trunk in this state. I don't suppose you've got any I.D., either?
What's a girl like you going to do in Nashville? Have you any money or friends? What are you gonna do, live in the streets?
He'd better provide you a way of gettin' there, too.
Uncle Red, don't you think you have a problem with your drinking?
Only when I can't get it.
I mean - don't you think you might need some help with your drinking?
No, I do quite well all by myself.
Mary was right to go back to her husband. What the hell did I have to offer a kid? Just honky-tonks and flop-houses. That's the life of a country singer, Hoss. Sound good to you?
It don't sound too hot when you put it like that, but it sure beats picking cotton and living in a sharecropper's shack.
You don't think he should be doing this, do you?
Do you? Knowing it might kill him?
Want me to level with you, pal? He's going to die anyway, and he knows it. And he knows that this is his last chance.
To be somebody. Did you ever feel like you wanted to be somebody? If he makes these recordings - who knows?
